posts.cooked:
I have been playing around with using the cOPRs available through TBA to use for match predictions, similarly to this older post (although my model is a simpler binary predictor) and some others. I think a trained model would be better suited for the relationship between alliance members (and the limits of the field) than a purely algebraic model. (E.g. two robots that can fill L4 on one alliance wouldn’t: they would likely fill L4 and L3. It seems possible but very tedious to create.)

Test matches are all subsequent matches (the week indicates the training data).

The results seem good (some overfitting?), but all of the matches were using data from after each event had ended (instead of from the previous matches), which makes it hard to tell if the model is actually an improvement over other methods.

So, my question is: Is there an easy way to access historical TBA data from the same event? Unless I am really misunderstanding something, using cOPRs from before each match should show realistic inaccuracies in early matches. If not, how are the TBA cOPRs calculated? I saw that you can get alliance scoring data per match through their API, would calculating them be similar to how TBA calculates OPRs ? (I have briefly looked through their repository, but I couldn’t find anything relevant.)

Any other insights would also be helpful, since I am neither a statistics nor a Python expert. Currently, I am using a LightGBM model with all of the available TBA statistics, as well as hyperparameter tuning on the lambda values, the num_leaves, bagging_freq, bagging_fraction, and feature_fraction. I have also tried several custom neural networks, but they were significantly slower to train and slightly less accurate.

Thanks.

link_counts.title: The Math Behind OPR — An Introduction – The Blue Alliance Blog

posts.name: Auxiliatrix
posts.cooked: Oh wow, this takes me back. I’d recommend reaching out to Eugene Fang from 604; he’s still very active in the FIRST community from what I know!

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
cafougner:

Unless I am really misunderstanding something, using cOPRs from before each match should show realistic inaccuracies in early matches

Yeah… I think you have to take a step back and see how fast some of these metrics converge. Frankly speaking (c)OPRs are not gonna be a great predictor for the first 75% or more of quals.

An EPA model that is aware of things like limited scoring locations or game-pieces is likely going to fair better for your applications. (Although there is nothing wrong with perusing the ML approach as an academic exercise).

Time series data with interdependencies and changing variance is a pain to work with in maching learning — not impossible, but I would reach for other tools before basic ML algorithms. (Source: my acedemic/professional work in climatology).  I put together a cascading model for limited scoring locations/gampieces for the 2025 game component EPAs, I can elaborate on that if there is interest. I never got around to doing a proper test vs vanilla Statbotics prediction (due to late comp season development).

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
cafougner:

So, my question is: Is there an easy way to access historical TBA data from the same event?

I am nearly 100% confident that the match-by-match evolution of cOPR as calculated by TBA for an event is not saved.

cafougner:

Unless I am really misunderstanding something, using cOPRs from before each match should show realistic inaccuracies in early matches. If not, how are the TBA cOPRs calculated?

If you re-compute the cOPRs match-by-match using the available match data then the issues created by trying to estimate contribution from an underdetermined linear system when only a few matches are complete will be “realistic”. TBA attempts to stabilize cOPRs early in an event using a minimum mean squared error (MMSE) solution to the system which involves the use of prior cOPR estimates.  Interpreting the terse TBA cOPR code is not for the faint-of-heart, but it’s available.

cafougner:

Any other insights would also be helpful, since I am neither a statistics nor a Python expert.

Why are you trying to improve match predictions?  Are you looking for a tangible benefit or are you just pursuing an academic exercise?  To the extent match prediction has value, what additional value would you expect to gain over something like the readily available Statbotics match predictions?

posts.name: Justin Tervay
posts.cooked:
paulonis:

TBA cOPR code

Fwiw that’s the match prediction code which is hidden by default.

The cOPR code is here: the-blue-alliance/src/backend/common/helpers/matchstats_helper.py at e5aa155f9cac5731db167d0d20806b7be82de0d3 · the-blue-alliance/the-blue-alliance · GitHub

We do components the same way as regular opr, but instead of total score we use the component value.

posts.name: Gabriel Krotkov (he/him)
posts.cooked:
cafougner:

So, my question is: Is there an easy way to access historical TBA data from the same event?

If you’re comfortable dipping into R, I maintain a package for myself and my students with a function that computes the (c) OPR progression over the course of an event. Take a look at scoutR::event_opr_progression() . If this is your first time using R, I have a new users vignette . The documentation still has a long way to go before it really onboards you without guidance from someone who knows R, but that’s all I’ve got right now

As an example, this line of code returns a dataframe for the 2025 CHS Glen Allen district event (“2025vagle”) with 36 columns (34 teams at the event, plus one for the number of matches and one for the number of matches per team) and 51 rows (68 matches played, the linear model is only defined starting with match 18.)

event_opr_progression(“2025vagle”, response_name = “autoCoralCount”)

Screenshot 2025-05-30 103058 1888×954 137 KB

Screenshot 2025-05-30 103058 1888×954 137 KB

Screenshot 2025-05-30 103058 1888×954 137 KB

link_counts.title: FRC Scouting Aide for R Users • scoutR

posts.cooked:
paulonis:

Why are you trying to improve match predictions? Are you looking for a tangible benefit or are you just pursuing an academic exercise?

The primary purpose for my project was to learn more about machine learning; making something that could be useful would be nice, but I wanted to learn more about different types of neural networks and how to create/use them.

With the models that I’ve made, I think I have a better (albeit basic) understanding of them, and I was interested in seeing how accurate of a model I could make. Although, from what @Skyehawk said, if accuracy is what I want, then there are better ways to approach the problem.

Skyehawk:

I put together a cascading model for limited scoring locations/gampieces for the 2025 game component EPAs

If you have the time, I would definitely like to see how you decided to implement this, even if it isn’t necessarily an improvement.

GKrotkov:

If you’re comfortable dipping into R, I maintain a package for myself and my students with a function that computes the (c) OPR progression over the course of an event.

As per my original post, this seems almost exactly like what I was looking for. I haven’t ever used R (and I also have many more side-project ideas now), but if I ever to come back to this I will definitely look into it.

Thanks for all the help, everyone!

posts.name: Eugene Fang
posts.cooked:
jtrv:

Fwiw that’s the match prediction code which is hidden by default.

I’d also like to call out that the match prediction code also uses a slightly different version of OPR that has been shown experimentally to be more stable with fewer matches played. Note that this is only used for match predictions, not for the (c)OPRs displayed on the event insights tab or available via the API.

Auxiliatrix:

I’d recommend reaching out to Eugene Fang from 604; he’s still very active in the FIRST community from what I know!
